March 24, 1955.

Mrs. R. Stewart,
17841 Broadway Rd.,
Cloverdale, B.C.

Dear Mrs. Stewart:

We have received the copy of Questionnaire No. 2 which you completed and returned to us recently. We are pleased to have this information for preservation in the Archives and wish to thank you for your interest and co-operation in making it available to us.

The nine pictures which you enclosed with your questionnaire have been sent to Regina in order that copies may be made of those which we wish for the Archives collection. After this has been completed the pictures will be returned to you.

Yours sincerely,

Evelyn Eager
Assistant Archivist

PIONEER EXPERIENCES: A GENERAL QUESTIONNAIRE

A word of explanation to the person answering this questionnaire.

It is difficult to prepare a general questionnaire on pioneer life because no individual who is asked to answer it has exactly the same experiences as another. Some of the questions here will not apply to your experience; others may prove impossible for you to answer, so don't worry about leaving blank spaces.

Use extra sheets if necessary. If there is not sufficient space to answer the question, use extra sheets or write details, or describe in particular events, etc., they help to answer the question.

This questionnaire is intended for persons who lived in Western Canada before 1914, and may be answered by anyone who has personal experience of the pioneer years whether born in this province or not.

If more than one member of the family can answer the questions, they should write them on separate sheets or apply for a separate questionnaire.

Other Questionnaires

Select those questionnaires which have been prepared or projected are listed below. Please mark the ones you would be willing to answer.

- All questionnaires
- Pioneer diet
- Pioneer schools
- Pioneer churches
- Pioneer recreation and social life
- Pioneer farming experiences
- Folklore in Saskatchewan
- Pioneer health and housing

Preservation of Questionnaires

All questionnaires will be preserved in the Office of the Saskatchewan Provincial Archives at the University of Saskatchewan as part of the permanent record of our province. Please send your completed questionnaires to:

Saskatchewan Archives Office,
University of Saskatchewan,
Saskatoon, Saskatchewan.

7. Mention any other places where you lived before coming to Saskatchewan, U.S.A.
8. How old were you when you first came to Western Canada? (You do not need to answer this question if you would rather not or you may use "I was a small child", "I was in my teens", etc.)
9. What were your reasons for coming West? TO RAISE WHEAT.
10. How did you learn about the West? (Through other people? Reading about it? Railroad or government information?)

A friend of mine who had been here

And I looked down the Country.
11. What did your friends and relatives think of your decision to come to Western Canada?

About it:

12. Did you travel by yourself or with a party (family, friends or other group)?

My Husband (William B. Stewart) came with his household good 4 miles. I came 40 miles.

13. What means of transportation did you use?

And my two sons came over after we traveled by passenger train. Handed at Craik, which was 22 miles from the homestead.

14. What incidents of the journey West do you remember? (People you met on the way, meetings with Indians, adventures on the journey, accidents or other excitement, etc.)

We stopped at St. Paul, Minn., S.O.T.A., U.S.A. Visited with my mother for two weeks.

15. Where did you first stay when you arrived in Saskatchewan?

My husband had a shack built so we drove out there.

16. Where did you settle or take up land?

East, west side of Long Lake.

17. Mention any other places where you have lived since coming to Saskatchewan.

Regina, Peter Glenn (and last few years Blumberg, R.B.C.)

18. How did you earn a living before coming to Western Canada? How, after you came?

FARMING.
11. What did your friends and relatives think of your decision to come to Western Canada?

They were not very pleased.

12. Did you travel by yourself or with a party (family), friends or other group?

My husband William B. Stewart came ahead with his household goods. 4 Mules / Cows. No children.

13. What means of transportation did you use?

Grand and my two Sons came over after we traveled by passenger train, hauled by CPR, which was 22 miles from the Homestead.

We started at St. Paul, Minn., S.O.T.A. U.S.A.

Accompanied with my Mother for two weeks.

14. What incidents of the journey West do you remember? (People you met on the way, meetings with Indians, adventures on the journey, accidents or other excitement, etc.)

15. Where did you first stay when you arrived in Saskatchewan?

My husband had a shack built so we drove out there.

16. Have you settled or taken up land? 2 Miles from Liberty.

East, West, Side of Long Lake.

17. Mention any other places where you have lived since coming to Saskatchewan.

REGINA, Later year.

And last year year. Blumberg, 13, c.

18. How did you earn a living before coming to Western Canada? How, after you came?

HARVESTING.
19. How often did you write to relatives or friends in your old home?

20. If you got married, give the name of your husband or wife along with the date and place of marriage.

21. Did anyone else come to Saskatchewan because of your recommendation it was a good place to settle?

22. If other members of your family (brothers, sisters, parents, etc.) came West tell when they came and where they settled.

23. In these particular experiences of pioneer days that stands out in your memory which you would like to record?

My husband took sick 1906 and passed away Feb. 1907 my two boys and I were left alone. A new country Son age 13 1/2.

24. Did you travel about much in the early years? (For business, attending church, visiting friends, etc.) How often? How far? By what means of travel?

NO. We were always getting land

Walter Stewart

26. If you owned a car before 1914, when did you buy it? What make?  
Ford.

27. Where was your trading center? How far from your home?  
CRAIK, K. and 22 MILES.

No we used our new town r. LIBERTY.

29. How often did you shop in the early days?  
In Summer every 2 weeks.

30. When (if ever) did people in your district first start going to town regularly on Saturdays?  
As soon as the town was made.

1913. BELL Co.

33. When you came to Saskatchewan the first time was it with the idea of staying permanently? Or did you make up your mind after trying it out? When did you make this decision?  
WE CAME TO STAY.
